intro: Mascagnia sepium var. macrophylla, commonly known as the large-leaved horse chestnut, is a variant of the horse chestnut tree native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its large, palmately lobed leaves that are typically 10–20 cm in diameter. The plant produces showy, white or pale yellow flowers in panicles during the spring, followed by spiny, woody fruits. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its striking foliage and floral display. The species is relatively drought-tolerant and thrives in well-drained soils.
